review_title: Nice place to work. Core values: Agile, Bold, Collaborative.
pros: Collaborative and open culture, actively propagated as The GovTech Way to encourage positive behaviours, and excellence in execution. Strong engineering capability in the products team. Strong recognition of the importance of design in the services team. CE who cares and makes it a point to engage the staff at numerous sessions, as well as the wider public service. Salary is better than the rest of public service. Learning opportunities and emphasis on competency development. Meaningful work. But a lot of compliance issues and deadline pressures plus the agencies are demanding leading to high workload. Depends on which agency you're deployed to. Overall very happy in GovTech as it has a positive culture and nice people who are trying to do their best.
cons: Auditing and compliance. Pressure placed on agencies, which fall back to GovTechies to implement. Tight resources. Agencies question the pricing and manning. Lots of PowerPoint, red tape and approvals. But improving. Now IM8 implementation is more consultative.

review_title: Good place to work, if you are in the right division
pros:
- Senior management making effort to modernize org culture. (I've been here for "a while", all I can say is it's way better than when I first started) 

- Reasonable compensation package (If money is your main consideration, then you should be looking elsewhere.) 

- Flexible work arrangements (highly dependent on where you are deployed/based)
cons:
- Face-palm moments when dealing with bureaucracy (we often forget that GovTech is just one of many agencies in the public service) 

- "Turf" wars happening at SLM & divisional levels. (As much senior mgmt try to portray otherwise, you still get the sinking feeling regularly) 

- Attempting to measure/rate professions with different specializations using a standard set of matrices. (seriously?)

pros:
- Bonus is good for people that performed well
- Closer connection to higher management(eg. Director level)
- Flat structure, technically no 'boss' but there still is.
- Claims process is fast and good
- Work is meaningful if you care about contributing to the country/citizens
cons:
- Pay is not up to industry standards.
- HR looks modern, but really isn't. Still tied by the WoG guidelines.
- Work is 'startup' style, which isn't a thing when you partner with agencies that has thick red-tapes. Startup style just means you have a easy road early on, pay the price down the road.
- Working speed is dialed down compared to private sectors
- Power struggle between GovTech and agencies partnership frustrates the execution level staff

pros: Surrounded by collaborative A players

review_title: Great workplace hampered by poor middle management
pros: Great renumeration package, with many opportunities to create value for the public good. Good career progression if you have a decent middle management to support you.
cons:
Some middle management (e.g. Deputy Directors, Directors) are undecisive/afraid to make decisions and sends working team on a wild goose chase, wasting project time and resources. 

Too much mundane tasks taking up time - implementing backend initiatives, remediating security scan findings, procurement, contract management, supporting end users. Staff turn overs lead to high workload for team members, too many short term contractors causing handover issues and corporate amnesia.

90% time spent on operational tasks, 10% on actual BA tasks. Doesn't create good career value if done long term.

review_title: Good Jumping Board, Bad Career Progression Company
pros:
When joining as Junior grade (D-F), you get very competitive pay. If planning to stay for less than 2 years, this competitive pay grant you bargaining chips to negotiate higher pay for your next job.  

Good exposure for freshies to know how SG Gov slowly progress digitally while having all the "red tapes" and traditional processes in place.
cons:
No appreciation for experienced Junior grade staff who are getting similar pay (some lesser since they started out with way lower based pay then) as newly joined Junior grade, but will be expected to carry more load and responsibilities.

Digitally savvy company but majority of experienced grade staff requires digital knowledge software upgrade. You will be surprised that there are experienced grade staff whom don't know how to change directory using bash T.T

review_title: Among the more progressive gov agencies
pros:
The mission and objectives are meaningful, and it's among the more progressive gov organisations. There's a strong private sector representation in the org, so that helps to shape the culture.

Salaries are benchmarked to the tech sector and are competitive. Of course, don't expect the same as at the top tech companies. 

Some bureaucracy is inevitable as there is a need to be accountable for how taxpayers' money is being spent and projects can impact the lives of ordinary people and the industry, so decisions can't be taken lightly.
cons:
Red tape is painful but usually there're reasons for them, so just deal with it as best as you can.

Also, the experience can differ greatly depending on whether you are at the HQ or seconded to other gov agencies. For the latter, you would have to adhere to the culture and processes of the org you're emplaced at, and it could be vastly different from the HQ side.

review_title: Great team and culture, bogged down by archaic HR policies
pros:
Great team to work with.
Good working culture, with competent boss.
There are lots of learning opportunities in the company.
Good to have GovTech in your CV.
cons:
Job grade meant to be based on assessed skills and competencies, yet HR will aggressively try to find the monetary value of the candidate - such as current or expected salary - derive job grade based on the monetary value, and then take the lower one. 

This is bad. Should a candidate be lowballed in his/her previous job, it would mean his/her grade would lag by a few grades than his/her assessed potential, and that wrecks career progression. Should the candidate realized where his/her grade stands in the whole of GovTech once he/she is in, it either leads to infant resignation, or if stay on, a lack of will to continue to strive for the company.

pros: 1. Great opportunity to grow in your career in term of job role, salary and recognition 2. Steep learning curve to acquire most in-demand skills. 3. Excellent rapport from leaders and peers

review_title: Senior management needs to manage expectations better.
pros:

Senior Management team hyped everyone up for a pay adjustment -- known as MDR internally (Market Differentiated Roles). For context this is a list of roles (mostly tech) and was told that there would be a pay adjustment to match market rates as long as your role falls in one of the positions.

Fast-forward to when everyone is expecting to receive the MDR adjustment, the management announced during a company-wide meeting (GovTech con) that it will only apply for employees who are a certain pay grade and above. Essentially junior staffs do not receive the pay adjustment.

review_title: Mid-careers beware. Don’t just look at the packaging.
pros:
Note: This experience was months prior to the current pandemic situation:

1) Colleagues (most) with great knowledge in their chosen field.
2) Senior Management leaders who genuinely care for their staff.
3) With a positive mindset, you can acquire a lot of experience that may be useful in future job roles, externally (what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger). You need to be self-motivated to remember why you’re here in the first instance.
cons:
1) If you’re a “non-techie” deployed in a highly technical department, learning curve is already steep. Yet, mid-level supervisors have high level of ego and Low EQ when working with some of them (example, I was even shouted at in the morning in a room of 20 plus colleagues simply for seeking clarification). All this will become a vicious work culture cycle. These people should find some place to flex their ego muscles.
2) Team lead(s) who only care for themselves while exploiting the effort of the rest of the colleagues. At one point, we even have to come up with an “SOP” so that these guys can be held accountable. What a waste of resource.
3) Beware if you’re “overly passionate” in your role (warning to mid-careers especially). While you may want to go all in with various recommendations or initiatives to improve operational processes, not every senior leader views it similarly (even though the CEO may approve of it). End of the day, it’s “who really runs the organisation”, will get their suggestions backed up and operationalised (or when the sh*t hits the fan, and they start asking if you’ve looked into it). Really need to “learn and play politics”.
4) As a public sector agency, you must accept that “white horses” are plenty (and even higher than that caliber), so focus will be on them (example, 2 persons can read the same script, but both carry different weight).
5) SNDGO “co-oversees” GovTech. Lots of interaction between these 2 entities, but the folks in SNDGO normally have the final say (whether they’re experienced or otherwise).
6) During exit interview, HR staff was just “asking questions” for the sake of interviewing. A number of times even dozed off. So…. It’s your guess how they view feedback (even on your final day).

if you divide the amount of OT u do after work including weekends and late nights, your hourly rate is worse than working as a fresh grad elsewhere. 

money can earn but health cannot recover, don't throw your health away chasing money. this comes from someone who had less than 5-6 hours of uninterrupted sleep for 2 years.

if you want to convert perm just use the "I am resigning" they suddenly will have headcount...

pros:
Salary higher than SMEs. 
Very nice hoodie.
cons:
1) Senseless bureaucracy. 
     Why are we still filling Microsoft Office forms for various deployment requests to higher management who are barely involved/knowledgeable of what is happening? This defeats the purpose of CICD
    Why are we forced to complete certain compulsory courses even though we are the subject matter experts and the courses are usually elementary(cybersecurity, data science, etc) ? So as to fulfil someone's KPI? which is a complete waste of time. 
   Why are we installing every vendor application under the sun in our servers to cover some obscure IM8 edge cases which will never happen? This affects system stability and requires extra effort to maintain, all done by that 1 engineer since the rest of the cybersecurity guys are only doing policies, lol
    Why should we follow IM8 to a T, even for the auditors, when some rules are obviously archaic? (eg. Manual log reviews every month?Ever heard of automation, rules/ ML?)

2) Inconsistent standards 
    The cybersecurity context is confusing. Cybersecurity policy people are often confused about the standards themselves and like to hold unnecessarily long meetings, sometimes with no outcomes, to discuss about recurring cybersecurity themes. This results in situations like projects with similar risk profiles having different cybersecurity standards or the one with higher risk having no cybersecurity standards at all. 

3) Paper-pushers more than doers
     IT projects, managers to engineers ratio, 3:1
   With too many managers, everyone wants to contribute to an everchanging project plan
    Cybersecurity people like to give blanket advice without understanding nor implementing

4) Political workplace
     To be a lifer where budget is project basis and limited, one needs to play the survival game by putting the rest down. Some are clearly doing that well. A few more and the dept is heading for an implosion. 

5) Lack direction
    Projects that are variants  of each other serve no meaningful purposes and are a huge waste of taxpayers money.

6) Archaic HR rules
    The bar for non-associate  level  from the competency framework is too  low. One may have enough skills to lead a project and checks the relevant competency level from 2 onwards(mid level up), be consulted by higher ranks on technical stuff and still be an associate, possibly due to <4 YOE.

cons: Lateral mobility for exposure to a broader range of projects is highly dependent on the team or department that you're in. More transparency around issues such as team restructuring would be appreciated.

review_title: One of the better govt places (not the best, not the worse, still govt)
pros:
1. Competitive pay for the number of years of experience - one of the best in the public service.
2. Although Investment banks & FAANG can pay more, the dollar per hour ROI for GovTech is more.
cons:
1. It is still government, don't let the rest of reviews kid you. Doing administrative work 8 hours a day is expected once you are close to being a first level manager (having one person reporting to you). If you are a fresh graduate, the administrative work is probably "reasonable" (maybe 1 - 2 hours a day?)
2. For people with less than 3 years experience - expect slow progression if you are not in a "fast track" management/talent program. For experienced hires, expect promotions to be given to people with connections or "parachuted" from SAF, etc. That said, if you are in one of these groups, apply immediately (this is a plus point for you).
3. There are quite a number of dishonest people around as it is government. Everything needs to be in "black and white". (other government agencies are worse, so maybe it is a plus point?)

review_title: Simply not Agile, Bold and Collaborative
pros:
Good place for entry level engineers to start and learn new technologies.

You will meet some capable people genuinely wanting to contribute to the nation, especially during the COVID situation, not just in Govtech but in the various agencies.

Some groups, mostly in HQ, are moving in the right direction in terms of actually adding value, new tech to public service. My rating is mainly for the department I was assigned to.
cons:
Lots of overtime due to inefficient processes and middle management not willing to even try to clear the issues, that are beyond the control of staff working on the ground. Not ideal for people that worked for many years in highly productive private sectors with good work life balance.

You may encounter toxic leads and managers (see link), who will do anything (bully, lie, sycophants) to make themselves look good for promotion and grading. So just watch out. (Google on dealing with jealous manager) . The thought of paying taxes to these leads/middle managers simply puts people off.

Usually people get promoted not because of the value delivered from their work, but doing things like presentations or "volunteer" in some extra activities or actively participating in chatgroups, that do not add value to their core work or to the public. 

There is a strong fear of failure within the organisation, so people are wary of taking challenging tasks, blame others when things don't go well, or follow the old way of working so to have a flawless record for their performance review based on a bell curve. This is somehow ironic considering the values Agile, Bold and Collaborative that they kept espousing.

- Red tapes and lack of maturity in knowledge management/devops/agile is hurting the velocity in which change can be effected. Projects typically take 3 years to even drive impact. Some projects take 6-12 months in planning stage due to budgeting restriction and security compliance requirements of using cloud
- Management which lacks technical expertise/exposure are unable to strategically plan for long term. As such projects are stuck in a vicious cycle of playing catch up and getting obsolete by the time it is completed

- Many Product managers are more of project managers which lacks proper product vision and product development mindset.
- Hire amazing people with amazing skill sets but end up not using them to full potential due to red tapes

review_title: Google-esque, a great place to start your career and play an active part in the Smart Nation Initiatives
pros:
People at the working level are earnest, open and inclusive. GovTech is the Google of all government agencies where you are surrounded by people motivated to harness the capabilities of technologies for public good. 

The people working at all levels are deeply motivated to deliver the highest quality of work to the citizens of Singapore. You can never learn how the government works from a book or an article. The only way to learn is through time spent and experience gained through sweat. It is not just about the tech but the people and processes behind them as well.

As long as you don't give up, the agency will not give up on you.
cons: The agency values experience in the government above the knowledge and expertise previously acquired in the private sector. Consequently, the longer you work for the agency, the more attractive your newly acquired experience becomes.

pros:
can never get fired.

pleasant candidate experience

in-house circus
cons:
Combative finance:

1) treat engineers like petty thieves, collusion often gets tabled in procurement conversations. Even over small(<100) transactions.
2) continuously challenging domain experts on technical reasons to select specific equipment for work.
3) stricter procurement rules compared to other agencies. in govtech utilizing discounts from vendors is a no-no. I have found out from friends in other agencies that while there is such a rule, it is not enforced (for obvious reasons)

Bizzare hr:

1) technical performance assessment by technical leaders can be challenged by hr. (apparently it is just impossible for any individual to outperform engineers from a different team)
2) DTS: implementing a water-ed down FAANG-style interview only for current employees to justify pay raise. (why don't we just assess people based on what they deliver at the company?)
3) performance assessment has this self-reported competency assessment framework thing, which is ridiculous. basically, u report your own competency on a pre-defined list of skillz. HR will treat this list as exhaustive and un-contestable. So, if your skills are not listed, HR will deem you unskilled. Ironically, I have found that HR is also listing skills not found in this framework, in govtech job listings.

review_title: Look beyond the well calibrated branding, they don't quite walk the talk especially HR
pros: Products developed are meaningful especially so that it has a direct impact on citizens life. CE is a good leader who is realistic and provides good guidance and direction. Physical environment is good, mainly wfh and you have to book a desk to return to office and given a locker. There's a tech bar for you to troubleshoot IT issues. Branding of GovTech is good as it is well calibrated and staged.
cons:
There is only so much branding can do to attract pple to join. Well branding can bring up the organization's attractiveness but once the staff joins, the experience is highly dependent on the division's culture and the middle management leading the department or division. I have witnessed people leaving their jobs after experiencing biasness, prejudice and some verbal bullying by their managers or more senior colleagues. 

Workday as a platform is a pain. It is not well designed or catered to users needs. No matter how we feedback on usability, it needs to go through many layers and many of times it goes into a black hole. Leaders and middle managers do not seems to understand such issues and just delegate the problem to another staff to solve the problem.

Middle managers and HR not walking the talk. During discussion with them on job rotation, the managers and HRBP gave very superficial and demeaning answers e.g. pls find your own rotation or find another job. When asked if there’s an opportunity to convert to perm they gave lots of excuses and empty promises. When asked if can go for course to pick up skills, they said only if u finish this project. Clearly, they are not here to support your career growth.

review_title: Depending on who your boss is, office climate can be toxic
pros: Generous training, pro-family staff benefits, great "kampong" interaction area, well-stocked pantry.  Good CEO - although no tech background, he is quick at grasping key concepts and issues, gives grounded advice and clear directions.  Stands with staff to withstand occasional aerial bombardment from oversight Ministry. Attempting to rejuvenate & grow organisation, rebuild engineering capabilities. Ambitious plans.
cons:
Organisation is hierarchical and reports need to crawl through the layers. Majority of eunuchs in oversight Ministry are clueless about tech. Top Eunuch is high maintenance, and meetings with him is high risk, as anything deemed philosophically deficient is immediately napalmed, carpet bombed and jettisoned (if anything is left). 
Show over substance. Ideas copied from elsewhere can be sold as sexy innovation, and rewarded with resources and promotion.  
Young punks stealing limelight. Mutual distrust between the 2 campuses. Both sides think its own work is more important than the other, with the other side overrated. 
Toxic office climate under some old bird senior management. After re-org, new boss systematically installs own kaki.  Managers who are obnoxious, blunt and bullying get promoted. People can be rank conscious - junior staff treated with less importance, royalty opinion has more weight. Slave driver behavior. Unreasonable turnaround time; expected to work late into the night, no dinners, over weekends, no appreciation.
A senior leader was publicly described on stage as "ruthless".  That comment about her was supposedly made in jest.  You decide.

pros:
Moving towards an open culture. Dressing flexible as "where in Rome, do as Romans do". Work attire f you happen to meet external parties. Lots of fun events going on. 

People in GovTech are generally nice. You don't get the "old guards" kind of political thing going on here. In my opinion, GovTech is a mix between a startups open culture and the traditional Singaporean culture.
cons:
Not valued. GovTech introduced a management and technical track, says staff gets to choose where he or she wants to be. Turns out it's not true. Outspoken staff who has no technical knowledge but able to articulate are groomed to be in technical track(specialist). Staff who truly knows technical are not appreciated and placed in management track(consultant). No avenue to change. HR will divert to your boss and your boss will divert to HR.

If you can say something that impress management even without knowledge and plus management favours you. You get promoted easier.

You will see colleagues who are less knowledgeable than you but yet more senior than you and higher grade. You can also see colleagues who are good at talking and making it seem like they are technically strong and the work done by you seemingly theirs.

Lastly, lots of procurement here. Technical folks may find themselves doing tenders, ITQ, ITT etc.

GovTech needs a few years to sort this out.

review_title: Technology is interesting, Govt made it boring...
pros: Good work-life balance, nice staff benefits, competitive salary and bonuses, generous training provided. Good place for retirees.
cons:
Excessive bureaucracy, numerous red-tapes and ridiculously rigid policies. This applies for procurement processes, implementing new IT collaboration tools, when resolving IT-related issues and simple user requests. To do a simple task needs to go through vast amount of admin work which is very redundant, repetitive and mundane. To top it all off, there will be endless audits through out the year which is more than enough to disrupt your daily work, operations and projects.

Seniors are friendly and knowledgeable in terms of work culture and gov policies. However, majority of them are not up to date in the latest technology trends and not supportive of new effective & creative ways of doing things.

review_title: Comfortable and good salary range but you have to play your "game" right.
job_title: IT Applications Project Manager in Singapore
pros:
Satisfactory salary.
Work-life balance, come to work on time and leave on time (dependent on project [if national project or not] and its phase).
Senior leaders are very forthcoming and down-to-earth.
Extremely good training budget per staff and as usual you have to pursue it yourself (but this is expected and you have to take advantage of this benefit if you want it)
cons:
Middle management put a lot of pressure to deliver on time although there are bound to be delays in the Government sector.
If you don't play your 'game', which is office politics, well enough, you may end up with the short end of straw, e.g. get tasked with all the 'extra/co-curricular activities', affected by the performance appraisal - mind you this is regardless of how much you have done for work.
Work, or more work, delivered does not equal to a better performance appraisal.

review_title: Joining the wrong team can mean seeing a whole lot of hype but experiencing none of the substance
pros: Great pay, decent benefits and bonuses. Iron rice bowl. Some interesting projects.
cons:
Decentralised and laissez-faire management style, which can bring a lot of pros if you are lucky and your team mates are adults. It is also common practice to bring in vendors from other companies and this dilutes the culture if bad fits are hired. Be prepared for a rather individualistic culture. 

Senior and middle management bank on this management style to allow problems to persist. Politics and ego problems can also be observed in certain departments and this creates greater impediments in projects as teams become too busy trying to appease these people. It is disappointing to watch tax payers' monies go to waste feeding egos instead of our citizens. 

HR department is a joke - bad at following up and caring for employees. Also happy to shift blame to employees and enjoys coming up with pointless frameworks. The only thing they have done well is their onboarding program, perhaps that is what they are good at - onboarding you to hell.

review_title: Behind the brand new facade is an obsolete thinking
pros: The welfare is good for staff with elderly and children, pay is somewhat above average. There's a vast array of deployment sites and HQ for you to move around and experience the different "culture" every 3 years. Good to stay if you are higher up, and looking for retirement.
cons: Very obsolete top down hierarchy and thinking, where upper management calls the shots based on simplified thinking. Bonuses are ridiculous when upper grades get twice the amount of lower grades. Lots of red tape and procedures where people bury each other so as to avoid doing work. No responsibilities taken, no courage to step up to get things done, spineless thinking relying on he-say, she-say. Expect to do more than your job scope dictates.

review_title: An Honest Review from my time as an Engineer.
pros:
Note: GovTech is a large organisation with many divisions, this review is written from my experience as an engineer in the Hive office.

Salary - Quite competitive compared to most technology firms in Singapore, good starting point for engineers with lesser experience. Don't be expecting FAANG or Sillicon Valley levels of compensation however.

Benefits - Pretty standard package for all employees: 18-21 days AL, a decent monthly flex allowance, okay medical insurance. One hidden thing that cannot be overlooked is the generous training budget; you are encouraged to constantly upgrade your skills.

Work - Many interesting projects going on here, all genuinely trying to tackle citizen-centric problems. Different challenges everyday (in a good way). You get to exercise not only your technical but also people skills.

People and Culture - The Big One. Very progressive, the attrition rate is mind-blowingly low in our neck of the woods. People here are driven,  passionate and technically strong. Plenty of autonomy for you to do whatever is neccessary for success. Leaders encourage failure and the learning that comes with it. Pretty flat hierarchy and teams generally feel psychologically safe. Camaraderie is strong and you never see politicking at least at my level.
cons:
All said above, one can see that there are polarising reviews on Glassdoor depending on which area you work in GovTech, or what stakeholders you are working for. There seems to be 2 main camps - our own engineering teams and those who have to manage projects (usually with external vendors).

Corporate generally leaves us to do our thing but there are starting to be tighter processes when it comes to things like performance reviews or career progression as the organisation grows.

As per typical Government organisations, you cannot fully escape the bureaucracy and red tape that comes with having to be accountable to the public.

pros:
(GDS department)
- Encourages skunkworks projects, empowers employees with autonomy to change things.
- Minimal office politics; people are more interested in getting work done.
- Very healthy culture and values.
- Fantastic and cosy physical work environment (Located at the Sandcrawler)
- Enthusiastic in trying out new technology and processes. Constantly stays current and up-to-date with the industry.
- Citizen-centric from the get-go, bottom line is impacting and improving the lives of citizens.
- Competitive remuneration in the public sector.
cons:
- Takes forever to buy a piece of hardware; takes a few months to procure a computer. Employees end up having to use their own laptops to work in the meantime.
- Employees have to use their own money to purchase services and claim afterwards e.g. cloud services, domain name registration etc.

+ Iron rice bowl unless you are not performing or value adding (or attitude issue)
cons:

Working in the government where none of the other agency's technical knowledge are up to speed. (and are not necessarily trying to ramp it up)
Unclear organisation structure

Too many rounds of restructuring over a short period. The spilt of IDA to GOVTECH and IMDA was ill conceived.  Many duplicative areas of work under the two new organization.

 Management decision on staff redistribution for the spilt was political and lead to brain drain. Smart Nation initiatives that have suffered prolong delays as a result. Management should have recognized the importance of the projects and not let politics cloud manpower decision making.

Management also hired incompetent new director that lead to total lack of direction for major Smart Nation projects and low staff morale. Issue was clear to see but no action was taken for more than half a year. Demostrates really week leadership by top management.

pros:

Feel like a valued team member.
During this pandemic, I see the work that GovTech is doing for public and the GovTechies who are powering these efforts and I'm very glad to be part of this kampong.

pros: Work life balance, incredibly generous training budget and overseas travel opportunities, challenging projects, flexible working arrangements.
cons: Lots of red tape and legacy systems to deal with. Politics can be quite bad depending on which team you’re working with. Progressive vision, but middle managers often have a “let it stay broken” kind of attitude to problem solving. Senior management and technical leads are quite hands-off. You can go to them to share your challenges and get advice, but don’t expect much actual support or action.

cons:
This review is for the part of GovTech that's not Hive.

This part of the organisation is mostly driven by tenders and procurement. Despite what all the glitzy recruitment activities may suggest, fairly little hands-on technical work goes on at the HQ.

Some bosses in supposedly technical roles do not have much deep technical knowledge and have to rely on their more junior staff to provide insights.

The messengers are the ones who score points with senior management and get promoted, not those doing the actual work on the ground. Also, it depends a lot on the boss you work for and the type of work they assign you. Some bosses do not see it as their priority to fight for their staffs' promotion, and they turn around to blame their staff for not being vocal enough etc.

The so-called technical specialists do more administrative and logistical work rather than anything requiring deep technical content. It becomes quite difficult to develop and retain technical skills. It's hypocritical for people to pride themselves as subject matter experts in certain areas when all they do is manage projects and contracts. There are initiatives to relieve staff of such non-tech work and focus more on core technical functions though, but change is slow. Besides, other than these non-tech work, it's not clear what other things technical specialists can do once they are relieved of such drudgery.

People who thrive are the extroverted ones who can micro-management, pressurise vendors and argue their way through. Those with technical capabilities are not appreciated. The ability to bs is a valuable skill to have, both within and outside of the organisation.  Timeline for delivery is prioritised over quality. There is the blame-the-vendor culture.

Generally, it feels like a place where one regresses to mediocrity, and not to do better. Thanks to the nature of the work, there is little impetus for personal professional growth. Those who want to strive for more are seen to "spoil market".

Opportunities for yearly overseas conference attendance are given to the directors but eventually little or no sharing happens. Seems like a waste of taxpayer's money. Money would have been better spent on training for more junior staff. At best, junior staff only gets to go overseas once in their time with GovTech, if at all.
